Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery closed vessel, possibly a pyxis lid; exterior: to centre, painted rays bounded by band of staggered added red dots and red band over top of black band; outside, black-figure decoration consisting of youth in tunic riding horse to right (most of horse's head and lower legs; red dab on rider's cheek and horse's flank), possibly holding stick upright; at right, tail of second horse.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (Catalogue no. 1332A)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 86, no. A108)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 221, no. 7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.153) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 72, pl. VI, no. 19)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
